abstractText: Structural Basis of Streptomyces Antibiotic Regulatory Proteins Activating Transcription 1 2 Yiqun Wang1, Xu Yang1, Feng Yu1, Zixin Deng1, Shuangjun Lin1 and Jianting Zheng1,2* 3 4 1State Key Laboratory of Microbial Metabolism, School of Life Sciences and Biotechnology, 5 Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China. 6 2Joint International Research Laboratory of Metabolic & Developmental Sciences, 7 Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China. 8 * Address correspondence to: Jianting Zheng, E-mail: jtzheng@sjtu.edu.cn 9 10 The final character count: 39960 11 12 Abstract 13 Streptomycetes are renowned antibiotic producers, with Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory proteins 14 (SARPs) acting as activators for antibiotic biosynthesis. However, the precise mechanism 15 underlying SARPs' transcriptional activation remains elusive. Here, we used cryo-electron 16 microscopy (cryo-EM) to unravel the interplay between SARP, DNA, and RNA polymerase 17 (RNAP) during transcriptional activation. The SARP domain of Streptomyces coelicolor AfsR 18 (SAS) forms a side-by-side dimer contacting the afs box centered at −29.5 relative to the 19 transcription start site. The upstream protomer binds to the direct repeat encompassing the −35 20 element while the σHrdB region 4 (R4) is positioned on top of both protomers, causing the removal 21 of R4 from the major groove of the −35 element. Both SAS protomers establish interactions with 22 C-terminal domain of one RNAP α subunits, while specific regions of the RNAP β flap tip helix 23 and β' zinc-binding domain also engage with SAS. Key interfacial residues accounting for 24 transcriptional activation were confirmed by mutational studies and in vitro transcriptional assays. 25 Overall, our results present a detailed molecular view of how SARPs serve to activate transcription. 26

MAIN TEXT 30 31 1. Introduction 32 Streptomycetes are multicellular bacteria with a complex developmental cycle(1). They 33 produce numerous bioactive natural products, including many antibiotics with important 34 applications in medicine and agriculture. Genome analyses of streptomycetes in recent years 35 have revealed their substantial biosynthetic potential. This capability makes streptomycetes 36 one of the most important industrial microbial genera. Complex regulatory systems tightly 37 govern the natural product biosynthesis of streptomycetes, involving both global and 38 pathway-specific regulators. Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory protein (SARP) family 39 regulators are prominent initiators and activators of natural product biosynthesis, and have 40 mainly been found in actinomycetes(2). Recently reported members of the SARP family 41 include ChlF2 from Streptomyces antibioticus and MilR3 from Streptomyces 42 bingchenggensis. ChlF2 activates the production of chlorothricin, known for its anti-43 inflammatory properties, and MilR3 stimulates the synthesis of an excellent insecticide 44 milbemycin (3, 4). SARP regulators exhibit a comparable protein architecture and binding 45 affinity towards similar recognition sequences (5). These regulators feature an N-terminal 46 OmpR-type DNA-binding (ODB) domain and a C-terminal bacterial transcriptional 47 activation (BTA) domain, collectively referred to as the SARP domain. The ODB domain 48 is characterized by a winged helix-turn-helix (HTH) comprising three α-helices and two 49 antiparallel β-sheets(6), whereas the BTA domain is all-helical(7). In contrast to “small” 50 SARPs that only contain a SARP domain, “large” SARPs possess extra domains at their C-51 terminals that are hypothesized to modulate the activity of the SARP domain (Fig. 1A). 52 "Small" SARPs are more frequently observed and extensively studied among actinomycetes, 53 compared to their "large" counterparts (8). 54
55 Streptomyces coelicolor AfsR (ScAfsR) is a pleiotropic, global regulator of secondary 56 metabolism belonging to the “large” SARP group, containing a SARP (Met1-Ala270) 57 domain, a conserved ~35-kDa dubbed nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain (NOD) 58 (Ala271 to Glu618), an arm domain (Arg619-Glu777) as well as a tetratrico-peptide repeats 59 (TPR) sensor domain (Asp778-Arg993) (9) (Fig. 1A). It activates afsS transcription by 60 binding to the promoter(10, 11). AfsS is a master regulator of both secondary metabolism 61 and nutritional stress response(12). It was presumed that upon binding of AfsR to a 22-base 62 pair (bp) binding box (afs box), RNA polymerase (RNAP) holoenzyme is recruited to the 63

afsS promoter and forms a ternary DNA-AfsR-RNAP complex, allowing for transcriptional 64 initiation(9). Additionally, ScAfsR also binds to promoters of PhoR-PhoP regulon members 65 such as pstS, phoRP and glnR, controlling the response to phosphate and nitrogen scarcity 66 (13, 14) (Fig. 1B). In vitro, a truncated ScAfsR protein containing only the SARP domain 67 (SAS) recognizes the afsS promoter and activates its transcription as the full-length AfsR 68 does, suggesting that the DNA-binding specificity of AfsR and its capability to activate afsS 69 promoter are determined solely by SAS (9). However, the detailed mechanism mediating 70 SAS-dependent transcription activation is still obscure. 71
72 The RNAP holoenzyme consists of a dissociable σ subunit that establishes specific 73 interactions with the −35 and −10 elements of the promoter in order to initiate transcription. 74 The positioning of RNAP is primarily influenced by the contacts between σ region 4 (R4) 75 and the −35 element, while the formation of an open complex is driven by the contacts 76 between σ region 2 (R2) and the −10 element(15, 16). The afsS promoter comprises a 77 consensus −10 element (CACTGT) but a suboptimal −35 element (TTCAGC). This 78 characteristic is commonly observed in streptomycete promoters (17, 18), which 79 complicates the identification of the −35 elements. The 22-bp afs box, centered at position 80 −29.5 relative to the transcription start site in the afsS promoter, overlaps with the spacer 81 between the −10 and −35 elements. It is composed of two 11-bp direct repeats (DRs), with 82 the upstream DR (−40 to −30) overlapping with the −35 element (−38 to −33)(19, 20). The 83 catabolite activator protein (CAP), also known as the cAMP receptor protein (CRP), is an 84 extensively studied transcription factor. The 22-bp CAP binding box (cap box) is centered 85 at –61.5 in class I promoters and at –41.5 in class II promoters(21-23). The binding position 86 of SAS suggests that it may possess a distinct activation mechanism. 87
88 Here, we used cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) to visualize a SAS-transcription 89 initiation complex (TIC) and to provide a transcription-activating mechanism that could be 90 generally used by SARP family activators. 91

ScAfsR, a prominent global regulator of secondary metabolism, possesses a widely 95 distributed SARP domain in all actinomycetes, enabling the activation of antibiotic 96 synthesis gene clusters. This characteristic has sparked interest in the function of ScAfsR, 97 with particular emphasis on its SARP domain, namely SAS. In vitro MangoIII-based 98 transcription assays demonstrated that SAS enhances transcription of afsS promoter (Fig. 99 1C), in agreement with the previous report (9). A 32 bp DNA probe (−45 to −14) containing 100 the afs box (−19 to −40) was used for the fluorescence polarization assays of SAS, in which 101 an average dissociation constant kD-ave of 89.5 ± 16.0 nM was obtained (Fig. 1D). SAS 102 purified to homogeneity was directly used to assemble the activator-TIC (Fig. S1). A DNA 103 scaffold is engineered from the afsS promoter, consisting of a 44-bp (−50 to −7) upstream 104 promoter double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) which contains the 22-bp afs box and the 105 consensus –10 element, a 6-bp (−6 to −1) non-complementary transcription bubble, and a 106 15-bp (+1 to +15) downstream promoter dsDNA (Fig. 1F). RbpA and CarD, two RNAP-107 binding proteins discovered in actinobacteria, can stabilize the TIC and have been found in 108 many TIC structures of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (24-26). Therefore, we combined SAS, 109 the DNA scaffold, RbpA, CarD, and RNAP σHrdB-holoenzyme, and subsequently separated 110 the TIC complex using size exclusion chromatography (Fig. 1E). Through in vitro 111 transcription assays, we observed that the presence of CarD and RbpA during the 112 transcription of the afsS promoter yielded results almost the same as those achieved with 113 the RNAP holo-enzyme alone. Furthermore, SAS maintained its role as a transcriptional 114 activator in the presence of RbpA and CarD (Fig. S2). 115
116 The final cryo-EM map of the SAS-TIC was reconstructed using a total of 95223 single 117 particles and refined to a nominal resolution of 3.35 Å, with ~3 Å at the center of RNAP 118 and ~6 Å at the peripheral SAS (Fig. S3). Local refinement focused on the SAS region 119 generated a 3.77-Å-resolution map. In the cryo-EM maps, the densities allowed 120 unambiguous docking of two SAS protomers, a 61-bp promoter DNA (−46 to +15), a σHrdB 121 subunit except disordered region 1.1, five subunits of RNAP core (α2ββ′ω), RbpA and CarD. 122 In addition, the cryo-EM density map shows a clear signal for an αCTD (Fig. 1G). The two 123 SAS protomers simultaneously engage the afs box and RNAP σHrdB-holoenzyme. The 124 overall structure of S. coelicolor RNAP in SAS-TIC closely resembles that in our recently 125 reported S. coelicolor RNAPσHrdB-Zur-DNA structure (PDB ID: 7X75, rmsd of 0.334 Å for 126

CarD binds the β-subunit and interacts with the 133 upstream double-stranded/single-stranded (ds/ss) junction of the transcription bubble (31), 134 while RbpA enhances interactions between β’, σHrdB and promoter DNA(32). 135
136 Interactions between SAS and afs box 137 The SAS-TIC structure elucidates the binding interactions between SAS protomers and two 138 major grooves of the afs box, with each protomer making contacts with one DR (Fig. 2A). 139 The contacts span the first eight conserved base pairs. In contrast, the last 3 base pairs don’t 140 make any contact with SAS (Fig. 2B). Overall conformations of the two protomers are 141 essentially the same with an overall rmsd of 0.4 Å. A dimer interface of ~1120 Å2 is formed 142 between the two SAS protomers, revealing a unique side-by-side arrangement (Fig. 2C). 143 Consistent with the previous report (9), size exclusion chromatography showed that SAS is 144 monomeric in solution (Fig. S1B). This suggests that the dimerization of SAS is occurred 145 specifically upon DNA binding. As a representative example of SARP family transcription 146 activators, the SAS folds into an N-terminal ODB domain (residues 25-111) and a C-147 terminal BTA domain (residues 120-270) (Fig. 2D). The ODB domain consists of three α 148 helices packed against two antiparallel β sheets. Two helices, α2 and α3, and the seven-149 residue connecting loop constitute an HTH DNA-binding motif, followed by a β hairpin 150 that contacts the strand between the helices α1 and α2. The BTA domain comprises seven 151 α-helices, of which the first three ones stand on the first β sheet and the first two helices of 152
the N-terminal ODB domain, burying an interfacial area of ∼860 Å2. The overall structure 153 of SAS protomers closely resembles EmbR (PDB ID: 2FEZ, rmsd of 2.8 Å for 247 aligned 154 Cα atoms) (7), a transcriptional regulator of M. tuberculosis, except that EmbR comprises 155 an additional C-terminal forkhead-associated (FHA) domain (Fig. S5). 156
157 The two SAS protomers establish a total contact surface of ~1300 Å2 with the dsDNA, 158 resulting in a 20° bend of the helical axis of the upstream dsDNA at T-30(nt) (-30T on the 159 non-template strand) (Fig. S6). The two ODB domains make similar contacts with DNA, 160

The N-162 terminal end of helix α1, the C-terminal end of helix α2, and the HTH loop make extensive 163 contacts with the backbone phosphate groups from C-40 to T-37 of the nt-strand, involving 164 both hydrogen bonds (S46 and Q48) and van der Waals interactions (W74, P79, S80 and 165 Q81). The recognition helix α3 penetrates the DNA major groove and is almost 166 perpendicular to the DNA axis. R87, R94 and K95 form salt bridges with the backbone 167 phosphate groups from T−35 to G-33 of the t-strand. The side chain of S91 makes a hydrogen 168 bond with the phosphate group of T−35(t). In addition to these nonspecific contacts with 169 backbone phosphate groups, the recognition helix α3 also establishes specific DNA contacts 170 (Fig. 2F). The R92 makes hydrogen bonds with the O4 atom of T-38(nt) via its guanidinium 171 group. The side chain of T88 makes a hydrogen bond with N7 of G-36(t). Consistent with 172 the structural observations, previous EMSAs show that changing the T-38(nt) of the 173 upstream DR or the corresponding T-27(nt) of the downstream DR to adenosine prevents the 174 binding of ScAfsR (20). However, changing the G-36(t) to adenosine doesn’t impair the 175 binding of ScAfsR since A-25(t) is observed at the corresponding position of the downstream 176 DR (20). Most residues involved in DNA interactions are highly conserved in both "small" 177 and "large" SARP homologues across various Streptomyces strains (Fig. 2G), including 178 Q48, W74, P79, T88, R94, and K95. 179
180 SAS engages with σHrdB R4, β FTH, and β’ ZBD 181 Both SAS protomers make contacts with σHrdB R4, burying a total interface of 800 Å2 (Fig. 182 3A). The upstream protomer contacts σHrdB R4 by its ODB domain, of which the HTH forms 183 a concave surface at the N-terminal of the helix α3 to enfold the N-terminal of the helix α4 184 of σHrdB R4. The negatively charged residues E76 and E77 in the loop connecting helices α2 185 and α3, and the residues E68 and D71 in helix α2 of the ODB domain form salt bridges with 186 R485 and R487 in σHrdB R4, respectively (Fig. 3B). The interface where the shape and 187 charge complement each other buries an area of ~320 Å2. The downstream protomer mainly 188 uses its BTA domain to contact σHrdB R4, with a buried surface area of ~480 Å2 (Fig. 3C). 189 The helices α3 to α7 of the downstream BTA domain form a “chair” to let σHrdB R4 sit on 190 it. The C-terminal of helix α4, the N-terminal of helix α5 and the connecting turn of σHrdB 191 R4 fit in a groove formed by helices α3 to α7 of the BTA domain. The R498 at the C-192 terminal of helix α4 of σHrdB R4 makes contacts with the E176 and V172 on the “chair back”. 193 The H499 in the connecting turn of σHrdB R4 is enfolded in an amphiphilic pocket formed 194

The K496 at the 195 C-terminal of helix α4 of σHrdB R4 makes a salt bridge with the E246 at the C-terminal of 196 helix α6 of the BTA domain. In addition, the HTH loop of the ODB domain forms 197 interactions with the loop connecting helices α2 and α3 of σHrdB R4. 198
199 The downstream protomer also interacts with the RNAP β and β’ subunits. The ODB 200 domain contacts the β-flap tip helix (FTH), the preceding loop (TPL) and the following loop 201 (TFL) of the β flap by the helices α1 and β2, and the second antiparallel β sheet (Fig. 3D). 202 The residues D71 and E76 of the ODB make salt bridges with the R805 of the β FTH. The 203 R59 at the C-terminal of the ODB α1 forms a salt bridge with the E817 in TFL. The R62 204 and T63 of the strand β4 connecting the helices α1 and α2 contact the R816 in TFL and the 205 K795 in TPL, respectively. The S106 in the loop connecting the strands β5 and β6 forms a 206 hydrogen bond with the main chain oxygen atom of the K749 in the loop following the first 207 strand of the β flap. The BTA domain forms interactions with the C-terminal of the β FTH 208 via the N-terminal of the helix α3, of which the R173 side chain is parallel to TFL. The 209 positively charged R67 and R69 region of β′ zinc-binding domain (ZBD) complements the 210 negatively charged E76 and E77 of the HTH loop of the ODB domain (Fig. 3E). 211
212 To confirm the importance of the residues contacting RNAP subunits in transcription 213 activation, they were replaced by alanine through site-directed mutagenesis. The mutants 214 were purified and assayed in MangoIII-based in vitro transcription assays as the wild-type 215 protein (Fig. 3F). Mutating residues R59, D71, E76 and R173 diminished the capability of 216 SAS to active transcription, whereas no obvious difference was observed between the T63A, 217 E77A, E246A, L247A and V249A mutants and the wild-type protein (Fig. S7). Mutating 218 residues E176, L211 and L243 resulted in insoluble proteins when they were expressed 219 under the same conditions as the wild-type protein. Some residues involved in RNAP 220 interactions are highly conserved in SARP homologues across various Streptomyces strains 221 (Fig. 3G), including T63 and D71 for interaction with the β subunit, L243, E246, L247, and 222 V249 for interaction with σ R4. 223
224 Interactions between SAS and αCTD 225 αCTD has versatility and important regulatory roles in modulating RNAP performance. In 226 E. coli RNAP, it recognizes specific sequences called UP elements in some promoters (33). 227 Many regulators have been reported to activate transcription by interacting with αCTD. The 228

SAS-TIC structure demonstrates that both BTA domains interact with the αCTD, burying 229 an interface area of ~660 Å2 (Fig. 4A). The αCTD is positioned on top of the helix bundle 230 of the downstream BTA domain. The helix α2 of αCTD interacts with the helix bundles of 231 both upstream and downstream BTA domains and is almost perpendicular to them. The 232 loops preceding and following helix α2, and the loop connecting helices α4 and α5 of αCTD 233 make contacts with the helix bundle of the downstream and upstream BTA domain, 234 respectively. The αCTD interface is predominantly positively charged (R259, R266, R287, 235 K292), complementing the negatively charged interface of BTA domains (D245, E246 and 236 D250 of the upstream BTA domain) (Fig. 4B). The residues R240 and L263 of the 237 downstream BTA domain interact with αCTD by electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions 238 respectively. As shown in Fig. 4C, the αCTD is required for SAS-dependent activation. Site-239 directed mutational studies further confirmed the importance of interfacial residues for 240 SAS-dependent transcriptional activation. Moreover, most residues mentioned above for 241 contacting the αCTD are highly conserved in SARP homologues, including R240, D245, 242 E246, and L263. 243

245 3. Discussion 246 Streptomycete promoters exhibit a wide diversity in sequences and transcription patterns to 247 finetune the secondary metabolism to synthesize numerous natural products in response to 248 environmental change. Genome-wide mapping of transcriptional start sites and ChIP-seq 249 experiments of S. coelicolor, the model antibiotic-producing streptomycete, reveal that most 250 promoters have a conserved −10 element, but a highly variable −35 element(17, 18). The 251 promoter −35 elements of M. tuberculosis, another GC-rich actinomycete, are also lowly 252 conserved(34). Guanosines at the position −13 and −14 and a transcriptional cofactor RbpA 253 are shown to be important for promoters lacking a consensus −35 element(35). RbpA 254 improves the interaction between the −10 element and σ R2 by binding to RNAP subunits 255 and the promoter −13 and −14 positions(32). 256
257 SARPs are well-known transcription activators of antibiotic biosynthesis. Here, we report a 258 strategy used by SAS to circumvent the recognition of a suboptimal −35 element and 259 activate transcription. Given the comparable protein architecture of SARPs and their 260 binding to similar motifs, SARPs are likely to function in a similar mode (Fig. 4D). The 261 position of afs box (centered at −29.5) is different from the binding boxes of typical class II 262

transcriptional activators (centered at −41.5). Consequently, the downstream SAS protomer 263 is closer to RNAP and makes extensive contacts with β and β’ subunits (Fig. 3A). Within 264 the scope of our investigation, SARP demonstrates the most comprehensive interaction with 265 RNAP among the studied transcription activators, encompassing all subunits of RNAP 266 except for ω, namely α, β, β', and σ subunits. Particularly, SAS functions as an adaptor that 267 physically bonds the −35 region and σ R4 together to compensate for the suboptimal −35 268 element. In reported class II activator-TIC structures (22), the σ R4 binds in the major 269 groove of the −35 element and interacts with class II activators such as CAP (21), SoxS (36) 270 and Rob (37) (Fig. S8). The transcriptional activation mode of SAS mostly resembles that 271 of the mycobacterial transcriptional activator PafBC termed “sigma adaptation”(30) (Fig. 272 S8F). PafBC inserts between PafBC-specific -26 element and σ R4 to facilitate the 273 recognition of promoters with suboptimal −35 elements. Our study showed that the “sigma 274 adaption” principle was widely adopted in actinobacteria, as indicated by the ubiquitous 275 presence of SARP regulators. In addition, both SAS protomers make contacts with the 276 αCTD, enhancing the ability to activate transcription by recruiting RNAP. Notably, 277 although many activators in reported TIC structures are dimer, they only use one protomer 278 to contact αCTD. In class I CAP-TAC structures, the downstream protomer contacts the 279 αCTD (21). In contrast, the upstream protomer contacts the αCTD in class II TAP-TAC 280 structures (22). Given the extensive interaction of SAS with RNAP, we raise a hypothesis 281 that SAS may also activate transcription by a “pre-recruitment” mechanism, as exemplified 282 by SoxS (36). But in vitro binding assay of SAS and RNAP demonstrates that SAS is unable 283 to form a stable complex with RNAP in the absence of DNA (Fig. S9). 284
285 The majority of filamentous Actinobacteria genera are known to possess SARP-type 286 regulatory genes, with examples including 98% of Streptomyces and 100% of Salinispora, 287 while the occurrence in Mycobacterium is relatively lower, at only 42% (38). "Small" SARP 288 regulators exhibit higher prevalence than "large" ones (8). These "small" SARPs hold 289 significant potential as tools for activating biosynthetic gene clusters, as evidenced by the 290 overexpression of SARPs to enhance the yield of natural products and the heterologous 291 expression of SARPs to effectively activate the expression of silent gene clusters (8, 39-41). 292
293 ScAfsR contains extra ATPase and TPR domains at the C-terminal that are postulated to be 294 responsible for regulating the functions of the N-terminal SARP domain (Fig. 1A)(9). 295 ScAfsR belongs to the signal transduction ATPases with numerous domains (STAND) 296

family (42). STAND proteins are presumed to keep in a monomeric inactive state by arm-297 based NOD–sensor autoinhibitory interactions or inhibitor binding in the absence of cognate 298 inducer molecules, resembling a folded hand (43-46). Activation involves a multistep 299 process of inducer binding, autoinhibition release, nucleotide exchange and conformational 300 changes that allow oligomerization and switch the protein to an active state (47). This 301 suggests that the C-terminal domains of ScAfsR may potentially serve a similar role in 302 sensing and transmitting signals. However, the precise mechanism remains unclear and 303 requires further investigation. 304
305 In summary, transcription activators of the SARP family have been exclusively found in 306 actinomycetes and play important roles in regulating secondary metabolism. Our detailed 307 structural analysis of SAS-TIC provides a molecular basis for understanding SARP-308 mediated antibiotic regulation in streptomycetes and offers potential optimizations for 309 antibiotic production. 310
311 312 4. Materials and Methods 313 Plasmids 314 The genes encoding SAS (residues from 1 to 270 of ScAfsR), RbpA and CarD were cloned 315 from the genomic DNA of S. coelicolor M145, and inserted into the pET28a via NdeI and 316 EcoRI restriction sites to obtain pET28a-SAS, pET28a-rbpA and pET28a-carD respectively. 317 Plasmids carrying SAS mutants were constructed using site-directed mutagenesis. Primers 318 used are listed in Table S1. 319
320 Protein Expression and Purification 321 The vector pET28a-SAS, pET28a-rbpA and pET28a-carD were transformed into 322 BL21(DE3) respectively. Induction of expression was achieved by adding 0.3 mM 323 isopropyl-β-D-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) and incubated for 12 h at 16°C and 220 rpm. 324 The cells were then harvested and resuspended in buffer A (50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 500 mM 325 NaCl, 10% glycerol, 1 mM β-mercaptoethanol and 5 mM imidazole). After purification by 326 nickel-NTA, the eluate was further loaded onto a size exclusion chromatography column 327 (SEC) (Superdex 200, Cytiva) equilibrated with buffer B (20 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 150 mM 328 NaCl, 5% glycerol) and the purified proteins were stored at −80 °C. Purification of S. 329 coelicolor RNAP and σHrdB was carried out as described previously (27). 330

331 In vitro transcription 332 The transcription activities are evaluated by MangoIII-based transcription assay as 333 previously described (27). DNA fragments containing the afsS promoter (−50 to + 15) and 334 the MangoIII sequence were used as transcription templates. Primers used are listed in 335 Supplementary Table S1. A gradient concentration range of SAS (ranging from 62.5 nM to 336 1000 nM) was combined with 10 nM of promoter DNA at 30°C for 10 minutes, followed 337 by supplementation of 100 nM of RNAP-σHrdB and 1 mM of NTPs in transcription buffer 338 (20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0, 100 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, 4 U RNaseIn, 1 μM 339 TO1–PEG–biotin and 5% Glycerol). The reactions were incubated for 15 min at 30 °C and 340 stopped by 0.5 ng/μL (final concentration) heparin. In the investigation of the impact of 341 RbpA and CarD on the functionality of SAS and the transcription of afsS promoter, as well 342 as subsequent experiments involving SAS mutants, RbpA and CarD were co-incubated 343 within the transcriptional system as global transcription factors (48-50). 500 nM (final 344 concentration) of SAS or its variants, RbpA and CarD were used. The reaction without NTP 345 was used as blank. A multi-detection microplate reader (Tecan Spark®) was used to 346 measure fluorescence intensities. The emission wavelength was 535 nm and the excitation 347 wavelength was 510 nm. 348
349 Fluorescence Polarization (FP) 350 A 32-bp afs box (−45 to −14) consisting of a 5′-conjugated FAM was synthesized, annealled 351 and used as the DNA probe. The reaction mixture contained 10 nM of labelled dsDNA and 352 0-5 μм purified SAS in binding buffer (20 mM HEPES, pH 7.5, 100 mM NaCl, 5 mM 353 MgCl2, 2 mM DTT, 5% glycerol and 0.1 μg/mL of poly(dI-dC)). After incubation at 30 °C 354 for 20 min, the fluorescence polarization of the reaction mixture was detected by a multi-355 detection microplate reader (Tecan Spark®) with excitation wavelength of 485 nm and 356 emission wavelength of 535 nm. Data from technical triplicates were fitted to a binding 357 equation Y=Bmax*X/(kD-ave+X) to obtain the kD-ave, where Y is the ΔmP measured at a given 358 protein concentration (X) and Bmax is the maximum ΔmP of completely bound DNA. 359
360 Assembly of SAS-TIC complex 361 To construct SAS-TIC, we used a DNA scaffold engineered from the afsS promoter carrying 362 a 6-bp pre-melted transcription bubble. The DNA was prepared by annealing nt-strand (100 363 μM final) and t-strand (110 μM). For assembly of SAS-TIC, 32 μM SAS was preincubated 364

We then loaded the complexes onto a 368 Superose 6 10/300 GL column (GE Healthcare), eluted with assembling buffer, and used 369 them directly for cryo-EM grid preparation. 370
371 Cryo-EM data acquisition and processing 372 SAS-TIC samples were added to freshly glow-discharged Quantifoil R1.2/1.3 Au 300 mesh 373 grids. In a Vitrobot (FEI, Inc.), grids were plunge-frozen in liquid ethane after being blotted 374 for 2 s at 16°C with 100% chamber humidity. The grids were imaged using SerialEM on 375 Titan Krios 300 kV microscopes with a K2 detector. The defocus ranged from −1.0 to −2.0 376
μm, and the magnification was ×130,000 in counting mode. 32 frames per movie were 377 collected with a total dose of 40 e–/Å2. For SAS-TIC, 3741 movies were collected. 378
379 The SAS-TIC data was processed using CryoSPARC suite v3.3.1. After motion correction, 380 patch CTF estimation, manual exposure curation, and template picker using selected 2D 381 classes from blob picker, two rounds of 2D classification were conducted (51). For SAS-382 TIC, 603659 particles were picked and used for ab-initio reconstruction (four classes). The 383 selected particles (193644 particles) were used for the second round of ab-initio 384 reconstruction (three classes) and heterogeneous refinement. The second 3D class (95223 385 particles, 49.2%) was selected and refined. Then, local resolution estimation and local 386 filtering were conducted to give final maps. By the process of particle subtraction and 387 masked local refinements to reserve only the signal around the SAS region, a local map with 388 improved quality was obtained (Fig. S3). 389
390 Cryo-EM model building and refinement 391 The initial models of S. coelicolor RNAPσHrdB, RbpA, and CarD were generated from 392 PDB:7X75 (27), 5TW1 (32) and 4XLR (31), respectively. The initial atomic model of SAS 393 was generated by AlphaFold (52). The model of the promoter DNA was built in Coot (53). 394 The models of RNAP, SAS and DNA were fitted into the cryo-EM density maps using 395 ChimeraX (54). The model was refined in Coot and Phenix with secondary structure, 396 rotamer and Ramachandran restraints (55). The validation was performed by MolProbity 397

Fig. 1. The overall structure of SAS-TIC. (A) Domain structures of Streptomyces antibiotic regulatory protein (SARP) regulators and Streptomyces coelicolor AfsR (ScAfsR). The N-terminal ODB (OmpR-type DNA-binding) domain together with the following BTA (bacterial transcriptional activation) domain is referred to a SARP domain. TPR, tetratricopeptide repeat; NOD, nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain. (B) Hypothetical scheme for the regulation by AfsR in Streptomyces coelicolor. (C) Transcription assays with increasing concentrations (62.5 nM, 125 nM, 250 nM, 500 nM, 750 nM, 1000 nM) of SAS. Data are presented as mean ± SEM from three independent assays. (D) Fluorescence polarization assay of SAS with afs box. The concentration of afs box was 10 nM. Error bars represent mean ± SEM of n=3 experiments. (E) Assembly of SAS-transcription initiation complex (TIC). The protein compositions in the dotted line boxed fractions are shown in the SDS-PAGE. (F) The afsS promoter fragment used for cryoEM structure determination. The -35 element, -10 element, the transcription start site (TSS) and the 6-bp noncomplementary bubble are denoted. The afs box is colored orange and contains DRup (the upstream direct repeat) and DRdown (the downstream direct repeat). The top (non-template) strand and bottom (template) strand are colored light green and dark green, respectively. (G) Two views of cryo-EM map. The map was generated by merging the consensus map of the full SAS-TIC and the focused map of the αCTD-SAS-DNA in Chimera X. NT, non-template; T, template. (H) Cartoon representation structure of SAS-TIC. The RNAP subunits, DNA, and regulators are colored as in the color scheme.

title: Structural Basis of Streptomyces Antibiotic Regulatory Proteins Activating Transcription
